PERSONAL
September 22, 1937
Mr. Harold M. Bixby
Vice President for China
Pan American Airways Co.
Manila, Phillipine Islands
Dear Harold:
I have read with mich interest your personal let-
ter of September 6th and "apologia".
You were certainly not alone in
misjudging
the course of developments in China over the last six weeks.
Certainly, I was not in a position to make any better forecast from this
distance,
although from what I heard from you and Bond and others who
have been in China and comparing it with the feeling I encountered
throughout New York, particularly at the Council on Foreign Relations,
it looks to me as though the people farthest from the scene saw the most
clearly.
This is probably just another example of the old difficulty of
not seeing the woods for the trees.
superiority of
way to criticize your analysis of the situation with which I do not agree,
let a your analyet one to
Even so, and without claiming any
judgment, I am going to stick my neck out in a
friendly
although frankly willing to admit that your opinion is as good or
better than mine.
possibly
The question is academic, of
course, in any
are faced with realities rather than theories.
case as we
In your letter of September 6th you
again bring up
the old Jack Dempsey simile which you used both
three years ago and
one
year ago,
which makes me inclined
to believe that your
thinking has gotten
into somewhat of a groove.
Now this Dempsey
simile,
while
very
graphic,
does not in my opinion meet the facts of the case.
You refer, for example,
to somebody of my name coming out from under the desk at the certain risk
of his life.
You overlook the
fact that when China
came out from under
the desk it came out with a brass
knuckle on each hand.
If,
in fact,
the
Chinese resistance had been one of
final desperation in circumstances simi.-
lar to the Dempsey-Morgan controversey,
China would not have come out so
well prepared.
It must have been in deliberate anticipation of exactly
what has taken
place that China expended so much on munitions, including
the aircraft of our friend Bill Pawley, during the last two years; that the
aviation school was operated at Hanchow; and that, if reports
are true, a
goodly number
of
expert German general staff
officers are
now available to
advise the Chinese high command.
It is my humble opinion that beginning
at least two
years ago the Generalissimo was prepared to come
to a complete
showdown with Japan,
the minute Japan made the next serious agressive
move, such as the Japanese activities around Peking during the first fort-
night in July proved to be.
